Description about the method used to perform the test on this analyte only.
Description about the method used to perform the test on this analyte only.
Description about the method used to perform the test on this analyte only.
Description about the method used to perform the test on this analyte only.
Description about the method used to perform the test on this analyte only.
Description about the method used to perform the test on this analyte only.
Narrative description of the key findings.

annotations.comment: For example: 'Pattern suggests significant renal impairment'. The content of the conclusion will vary, depending on the investigation performed. This conclusion should be aligned with the coded 'Test diagnosis'.

localizedDescriptions.en: A media file that is acquired or used as part of the healthcare process, and associated metadata.
Digital representation of the media file.

annotations.comment: If the file is stored locally, the actual content will be captured and stored using the Multimedia data type. For example: RTF or PDF for a document; JPG for an image; MP4 for a video; or WAV for an audio file. Full list of available media types: https://specifications.openehr.org/releases/TERM/latest/SupportTerminology.html#_media_types.  If the file is stored at a location outside of the health record, the detailed path to the file is captured using the URI attribute in the Multimedia data type. The Multimedia data type has many RM attributes such as the size of file and URI to an external source - see https://specifications.openehr.org/releases/RM/latest/data_types.html#_dv_multimedia_class.

localizedDescriptions.en: Descriptive name or title for the media file.

annotations.comment: A description of the content of the media file. Use an agreed standardised naming convention, if available. For example: "Right hand burn #1" or "Cardiology video consultation on May 2".

localizedDescriptions.en: The result of an imaging examination performed on an individual, using radiological techniques.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The name of the imaging examination performed.

annotations.comment: For example: 'CT abdomen'; 'Doppler ultrasound of renal artery' or 'Plain chest xray'. Coding with a terminology is strongly recommended, preferably a term specifying both modality and anatomical location, where possible. Examples of candidate terminologies are the LOINC Imaging Document Codes, RadLex Playbook or SNOMED-CT. Equivalent to DiagnosticReport.code in FHIR.

localizedDescriptions.en: The type of imaging device, process or method that originally acquired or produced the data used to create the images in the study.

annotations.comment: For example: 'XRay', 'CT scan', 'ultrasound', 'MRI', 'bone densitometry', 'tomography', 'mammography', 'nuclear medicine', 'PET', 'angiography', and 'fluoroscopy'. This data element may be redundant if the modality is clearly represented in the 'Study name'. Alternatively it may also be possible to autopopulate the 'Modality' from a coded 'Study name'. Coding of the 'Modality' with a value set is recommended, such as the DICOM CID 29 Acquisition Modality value set. Equivalent to ImagingStudy.modality in FHIR and Modality (0008, 0060) in DICOM.

localizedDescriptions.en: Description of the simple body site or region targetted for imaging.

annotations.comment: If the body site is specified within the text or code for 'Study name', then this field may be redundant. Coding of 'Target body site' with a terminology, such as SNOMED CT, is desirable. Equivalent to ImagingStudy.series.bodySite in FHIR.

localizedDescriptions.en: The status of the imaging examination result as a whole.

annotations.comment: The values have been aligned with the FHIR Diagnostic report status, with the exception of 'Entered in error' which is relevant only to a messaging-oriented paradigm. Other local codes/terms can be used via the Text 'choice'. In most use cases, only one status is applicable at any time, however this data element allows multiple occurrences for the use cases where there are a variety of types of status that need to be specified, usually within a template. Equivalent to DiagnosticReport.status in FHIR.

localizedDescriptions.en: The existence of the study is registered, but no result is yet available.
This is a partial (e.g. initial, interim or preliminary) result but data may be incomplete or unverified.
Verified early results are available, but not all results are final. This is a sub-category of 'Partial'.
The result is complete and verified by an authorised person.
Subsequent to being final, the result has been modified.
Subsequent to being final, the result has been modified to correct an error. This is a sub-category of 'Amended'.
Subsequent to being final, the result has been modified by adding new content. The existing content is unchanged. This is a sub-category of 'Amended'.
The result is unavailable because the test was not started or not completed (also sometimes called 'aborted').
The status of the result is not known.
Narrative description or overview of all clinical findings.

children.name: Imaging examination of a body structure
children.localizedName: Imaging examination of a body structure

localizedNames.en: Imaging examination of a body structure

localizedDescriptions.en: Findings on radiological examination of a specified body structure or region.
Identification of the body structure or region examined.

annotations.comment: For example: 'Liver', 'Right ankle' or 'Lymph node group'. Coding of the body structure with an appropriate terminology, such as SNOMED CT, is recommended. If the body structure has been fully identified in this 'Body structure' element, then the 'Body site' data element and 'Structured body site' SLOT become redundant.

localizedDescriptions.en: Identification of the area of the body under examination.

annotations.comment: For example: a lymph node group (body structure) which found in the 'Right axilla'. Coding of 'Body site' with a terminology, such as SNOMED CT, is desirable. If the body site has been fully identified in the 'Body structure' data element, this data element becomes redundant.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description of the imaging findings observed during this examination.
Single word, phrase or brief description that represents the clinical meaning and significance of all imaging findings for the identified body structure.

annotations.comment: Also referred to as 'Interpretation' or 'Opinion'. For example: 'No abnormality detected' or 'Free fluid present'. Coding of the 'Impression' with a terminology is permitted, if useful. Multiple occurrences allow for more than one coded impression. A narrative description may include a comparison with previous studies of the identified body structure, if appropriate.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about the imaging findings of the body structure, not captured in other fields.
Narrative description about the comparison of this examination with previous similar studies.

annotations.comment: Also use this data element to indicate if no comparison images and/or reports are available. Details about the images used for comparison can be recorded using the 'Comparison study details' CLUSTER, within Protocol.

localizedDescriptions.en: Assessment about the quality of the examination.

annotations.comment: Coding of the imaging quality with a value set is recommended. For example: 'excellent, good, fair, poor, and non-diagnostic'; or 'adequate, suboptimal and inadequate'.

localizedDescriptions.en: Single word, phrase or brief description representing a possible condition or diagnosis.

annotations.comment: This data element has multiple occurrences to allow for more than one differential diagnosis. Coding with a terminology such as SNOMED CT is preferred, where possible. This data element should be considered as mutually exclusive to "Imaging diagnosis", ie only either "Imaging diagnosis" or "Imaging differential diagnosis" in each instance of the archetype "Imaging examination result."

localizedDescriptions.en: Single word, phrase or brief description representing the likely condition or diagnosis.

annotations.comment: This data element has multiple occurrences to allow for more than one differential diagnosis. Coding with a terminology such as SNOMED CT is preferred, where possible. This data element should be considered as mutually exclusive to "Imaging differential diagnosis", ie only either "Imaging diagnosis" or "Imaging differential diagnosis" in each instance of the archetype "Imaging examination result." Equivalent to DiagnosticReport.conclusionCode in FHIR.

localizedDescriptions.en: A media file that is acquired or used as part of the healthcare process, and associated metadata.
Digital representation of the media file.

annotations.comment: If the file is stored locally, the actual content will be captured and stored using the Multimedia data type. For example: RTF or PDF for a document; JPG for an image; MP4 for a video; or WAV for an audio file. Full list of available media types: https://specifications.openehr.org/releases/TERM/latest/SupportTerminology.html#_media_types.  If the file is stored at a location outside of the health record, the detailed path to the file is captured using the URI attribute in the Multimedia data type. The Multimedia data type has many RM attributes such as the size of file and URI to an external source - see https://specifications.openehr.org/releases/RM/latest/data_types.html#_dv_multimedia_class.

localizedDescriptions.en: Descriptive name or title for the media file.

annotations.comment: A description of the content of the media file. Use an agreed standardised naming convention, if available. For example: "Right hand burn #1" or "Cardiology video consultation on May 2".

localizedDescriptions.en: Name of the radiological procedure used to capture the study.

annotations.comment: Coding of the 'Technique' with a terminology is permitted. Multiple occurrences allow for identification of one or more techniques.

localizedDescriptions.en: Details about a single imaging examination requested.
Unique identifier for the imaging examination order assigned by the radiology service.

annotations.comment: Equivalent to the HL7 Filler Order Identifier or DICOM Accession number attribute (0008,0050).

localizedDescriptions.en: Unique identifier for the imaging examination order assigned by the radiology service.
Unique identifier for the imaging examination order assigned by the radiology service.
Unique identifier for the imaging examination order assigned by the requester.

annotations.comment: Equivalent to the HL7 Placer Order Identifier.

localizedDescriptions.en: Unique identifier for the imaging examination order assigned by the requester.
Unique identifier for the imaging examination order assigned by the requester.
Identification of imaging examination requested.

annotations.comment: This can be useful in situations where the examination requested differs from the examination performed.

localizedDescriptions.en: A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
A framework to communicate the preferences of an individual for future medical treatment and care.
The type of advance care directive.

annotations.comment:
A short text description of the nature of the advance care directive. Coding of the type of directive with a terminology is preferred, where possible. It is expected that this is largely localised to reflect local policy and legislation.

For example, in the Netherlands, advance care directive types include, but are not limited to, 'Treatment prohibition', 'Treatment prohibition with completion of Completed Life', 'Euthanasia request' and 'Declaration of life'.

In the UK, advance care directive types include 'Advance Decision', 'Advance Directive' and 'Advance Statement'.

localizedDescriptions.en: The status of the advance care directive.

annotations.comment: Coding of the advance care directive status with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: The individual has an advance care directive.
The individual does not have an advance care directive.
It is not known whether the individual has an advance care directive.
Narrative description of the overall advance care directive.

annotations.comment: May be used to record a narrative overview of the complete advance care directive, which may or may not be supported by structured data. Details of specific structured findings can be included using CLUSTER archetypes in the 'Directive details' slot. This data element may be used to capture legacy data that is not available in a structured format.

localizedDescriptions.en: The conditions or situations in which the individual wishes the advance care directive to apply.

annotations.comment:
For example: dementia, brain injury, diseases of the central nervous system, and terminal illness. Coding with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

The advance care directive applies to all specified conditions if the individual can no longer make or communicate decisions about their medical treatment and is unlikely to regain the ability to make such decisions. Details of specific decisions that apply to different conditions or situations can be included using CLUSTER archetypes in the 'Directive details' slot.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about the advance care directive not captured in other fields.
The date/time that marks the beginning of the valid period of time for this advance care directive.
The date/time that marks the conclusion of the valid period of time for this advance care directive.

annotations.comment: 'Valid period end' may often overlap with 'Review due date'. However, they may need to be recorded separately in circumstances where a document has an extended period of validity but requires an interim review. That may be due to changed personal circumstances/events or local policy.

localizedDescriptions.en: The date at which the advance care directive is due to be reviewed.

annotations.comment: 'Valid period end' may often overlap with 'Review due date'. However, they may need to be recorded separately in circumstances where a document has an extended period of validity but requires an interim review. That may be due to changed personal circumstances/events or local policy.

localizedDescriptions.en: The date when this advance directive record was last updated.

annotations.comment: This may not be a formal review but e.g. a typo correction.

localizedDescriptions.en: Description of any legislation or other authoritative guidance that apply.

annotations.comment:
For example, 'In England and Wales, advance decisions are covered by the Mental Capacity Act.  Mandate: https://www.bma.org.uk/advice/employment/ethics/consent/consent-tool-kit/9-advance-decisions'. 

Or 'Jehovah's Witnesses believe that the Bible prohibits Christians from accepting blood transfusions. Mandate: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jehovah%27s_Witnesses_and_blood_transfusions'.

localizedDescriptions.en: Description of any legislation or other authoritative guidance that apply.
Description of any legislation or other authoritative guidance that apply.
Information about the physical or digital location of the Advance care directive.
Physical or digital location of the Advance care directive.
Physical or digital location of the Advance care directive.
Physical or digital location of the Advance care directive.
Anticipatory decisions about the overall intent of care and possible interventions (including treatments, activities, and diagnostic or therapeutic procedures), asserted by a clinician.
The overall intent for future care and treatment for the individual.

annotations.comment:
The proposed value set is based on the MJA reference. 
Coding the intent of care with an external terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: The condition is curable; all appropriate life-prolonging treatment will be offered.
The condition is treatable with potential for restoration to the previous state of health or a prolonged remission; all appropriate life-prolonging treatment will be offered.

The condition is incurable and progressive; active treatment of the underlying disease may be appropriate for specific symptom relief and/or short term life expectancy gains; focused on comfort, quality of life and dignity. Also referred to as 'Palliative'.
Life expectancy is short (hours or days); no active treatment of the underlying disease or treatment-related harm; focus on comfort, quality of life and dignity.
The intent of care decision is not known.
Narrative description about the logic and justification for the 'Intent of care' decision.
Narrative description about all advance intervention decisions, including the CPR decision.

annotations.comment: May be used to record a narrative overview of the advance intervention decision that reflect the specific circumstances for the individual. This includes any limitations, or conditional circumstances applicable, to interventions. This description may or may not be supported by structured data, recorded using the Per intervention cluster. If both this narrative description and Per intervention structured data is recorded, caution is required as there is a potential risk of divergence. This data element may be used to capture legacy data that is not available in a structured format.

localizedDescriptions.en: Decision about the extent of cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) intervention appropriate for this individual.
All appropriate cardiopulmonary resuscitation treatments should be attempted to save or prolong life.
Cardiopulmonary resuscitation treatments should be attempted, as specified in the 'Decisions description' narrative or as structured data in the 'Per intervention' cluster.

No cardiopulmonary resuscitation treatments should be attempted to save or prolong life. Also known as 'Do not resuscitate (DNR)'; 'Do not attempt resuscitation (DNAR)'; 'Not for resuscitation (NFR)' or similar.
The CPR decision is not known.
Details of the decision about possible treatments or activities that may be life-saving, life-prolonging or cause undesirable side effects.
Name of the possible treatment, procedure or activity.

annotations.comment: While this archetype is intended for all clinical decisions about possible future interventions, the proposed DV_CODED_TEXT value set for the 'Intervention' data element is deliberately not intended to be exhaustive. Instead it has been designed to be inclusive of most of the common life-saving treatments within an emergency context. The alternate choice of the DV_TEXT option can be used to add a local value set or bind to an alternative external value set within a template.

localizedDescriptions.en: Technique used to manually pump blood around the body during a cardiac arrest.
Use of electric shock to reset the electrical state of the heart.
Placement of a tube into the trachea to maintain an open airway, including a tracheostomy.
Artificial ventilation where invasive means are used to assist or replace spontaneous breathing.
Artificial ventilation where non-invasive means are used to assist or replace spontaneous breathing.
Insertion of a peripheral intravenous line.

list.label: Central venous line or any arterial line

localizedLabels.en: Central venous line or any arterial line

localizedDescriptions.en: Insertion of a central venous line or any arterial line.
Maintenance of hydration by means other than eating or drinking.
Provision of nutrients by means other than eating or drinking.
Medications used during an emergency resuscitation to prolong life. For example: adrenaline, atropine, sodium bicarbonate, calcium, other vasoactive medications.
Medication that supports heart function, including but not limited to: vasopressors, inotropes and chronotropes.
Medications to treat infections.
Therapeutic substance prepared from human blood including, but not limited to: whole blood; blood components; and plasma derivatives.
Insertion of a tube into the pleural space.
Insertion of an artificial pacemaker to control the heart beat.
Process of removing excess water, solutes, and toxins from the blood.
Transfer to hospital for assessment or admission.
Transfer and admission to an intensive care or high dependency unit.
Decision about the identified intervention.
The intervention is recommended.
The intervention is recommended only in specific circumstances, captured using the 'Preconditions' data element.
The intervention is not recommended.
The intervention decision is not known.
Description of the circumstance/s in which a 'Conditional recommendation' is applicable.

annotations.comment: This data element is only relevant if the 'Conditional recommendation' option is selected in the 'Decision' data element. For example:' "Transfer to hospital is only applicable in the circumstances where the individual suffers a fracture and requires immobilization for pain relief.#

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about the intervention decision, not captured in other fields.

annotations.comment: For example: the justification or rationale for the intervention decision.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description about awareness of the Advance intervention decisions by the individual.

annotations.comment: For example: the capacity of the patient to understand the decisions.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description about awareness of the Advance intervention decisions by family, carers or legal proxy.

annotations.comment: For example: the individual has no family.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about all advance intervention decisions, not captured in other fields.
The date and/or time when the Advance intervention decisions were last updated.
The date/time that marks the beginning of the valid period of time for the Advance intervention decisions.
The date/time that marks the conclusion of the valid period of time for the Advance intervention decisions.

annotations.comment: 'Valid period end' may often overlap with 'Review due date'. However, they may need to be recorded separately in circumstances where a document has an extended period of validity but requires an interim review. That may be due to changed personal circumstances/events or local policy.

localizedDescriptions.en: The date when review of the Advance intervention decisions are due.
Description of any legislation or other authoritative guidance that apply.

annotations.comment: For example: an advance care directive.

localizedDescriptions.en: Description of any legislation or other authoritative guidance that apply.
Description of any legislation or other authoritative guidance that apply.
Information about the physical or digital location of the advance intervention decisions record.
Physical or digital location of the Advance intervention decisions record.
Physical or digital location of the Advance intervention decisions record.
Physical or digital location of the Advance intervention decisions record.
A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
A clinical activity carried out for screening, investigative, diagnostic, curative, therapeutic, evaluative or palliative purposes.
Identification of the procedure by name.

annotations.comment: Coding of the specific procedure with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: The clinical or process-related reason for the procedure.

annotations.comment: Coding of the indication with a terminology is preferred, where possible. This data element allows multiple occurrences. For example: 'Failed bowel preparation' or 'Bowel cancer screening'.

localizedDescriptions.en: Identification of the body site for the procedure.

annotations.comment: Occurrences for this data element are unbounded to allow for clinical scenarios such as removing multiple skin lesions in different places, but where all of the other attributes are identical. Use this data element to record simple terms or precoordinated anatomical locations. If the requirements for recording the anatomical location are determined at run-time by the application or require more complex modelling such as relative locations then use the CLUSTER.anatomical_location or CLUSTER.relative_location within the 'Procedure detail' SLOT in this archetype. If the anatomical location is included in the 'Procedure name' via precoordinated codes, this data element becomes redundant.

localizedDescriptions.en: Statement that specified health information is not available for inclusion in the health record or extract at the time of recording.
Positive statement that no information is available.

annotations.comment: For example: "No information available about adverse reactions"; No information available about problems or diagnoses"; "No information available about previous procedures performed"; or "No information available about medications used".

list.value: No information about past history of procedures
list.label: No information about past history of procedures

localizedDescriptions.en: The date at which the absence was last updated.

An overall statement of exclusion about all Problems/diagnoses, Family history, Medications, Procedures, Adverse reactions or other clinical items that are either not currently present, or have not been present in the past.
Overall statement of exclusion about all procedures at the time of recording.

annotations.comment: For example: 'No previous diagnoses', 'No known family history', 'No known history of adverse reactions', 'Never taken any medications' or 'No known operations or significant procedures'.

localizedDescriptions.en: A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
An ongoing and persistent overview about medical devices that have been fitted or implanted.
Details about each device.
Identification of the specific device, by name.
Identification of the body site where the device is fitted/implanted.

An instrument, apparatus, implant, material or similar, used in the provision of healthcare. In this context, a medical device includes a broad range of devices which act through a variety of physical, mechanical, thermal or similar means but specifically excludes devices which act through medicinal means such as pharmacological, metabolic or immunological methods.  The scope is inclusive of disposable devices as well as durable or persisting devices that require tracking, maintenance activities or regular calibration, recognising that each type of device has specific data recording requirements.
Identification of the medical device, preferably by a common name, a formal fully descriptive name or, if required, by class or category of device.

annotations.comment: This data element will capture the term, phrase or category used in clinical practice. For example: <brand name><machine> (XYZ Audiometer); <size> <brand name> <intravenous catheter> (14G Jelco IV catheter); or <brand name/type> <implant>. Coding with a terminology is desirable, where possible, although this may be local and depending on local supplies available.

localizedDescriptions.en: The category or kind of device.

annotations.comment:
Not applicable if a category is already recorded in 'Device name'.
 Example: if the 'Device' is named as a 'urinary catheter'; the 'Type' may be recorded as 'indwelling' or 'condom'.Coding with a terminology is desirable, where possible. This may include use of GTIN or EAN numbers.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description of the medical device.
A numeric or alphanumeric string that is associated with this device within a given system.

annotations.comment: Often fixed to the device as a barcode.

localizedDescriptions.en: Name of manufacturer.
Date the device was manufactured.
Number assigned by the manufacturer which can be found on the device, and should be specific to each device., its label, or accompanying packaging.
The exact number assigned by the manufacturer, as it appears in the manufacturer's catalogue, device labeling, or accompanying packaging.
The exact model number assigned by the manufacturer and found on the device label or accompanying packaging.
The number assigned by the manufacturer which identifies a group of items manufactured at the same time, usually found on the label or packaging material.
Identification of the version of software being used in the medical device.

annotations.comment: When the medical device is an actual software application, record the version of the software using this data element. When the medical device has multiple software applications embedded within it, record each software component in a separate CLUSTER archetype within the Components SLOT - either as a nested instance of another CLUSTER.device archetype or using a CLUSTER archetype designed specifically for recording software details (but not yet available at time of this archetype development).

localizedDescriptions.en: Date after which the device/product is no longer fit for use, usually found on the device itself or printed on the accompanying packaging.

annotations.comment: This date usually applies only to single use or disposable devices.

localizedDescriptions.en: Unspecified identifier, which can be further specified in a template or at run time.

annotations.comment: Coding of the name of the identifier with a coding system is desirable, if available.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about the device not captured in other fields.
A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
Measurement of the body weight of an individual.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The weight of the individual.
Height, or body length, is measured from crown of head to sole of foot.

annotations.comment: Height is measured with the individual in a standing position and body length in a recumbent position.

localizedDescriptions.en: Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The length of the body from crown of head to sole of foot.
The characteristics of spontaneous breathing by an individual.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The frequency of spontaneous breathing.
The rate and associated attributes for a pulse or heart beat.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The rate of the pulse or heart beat, measured in beats per minute.
A measurement of the body temperature, which is a surrogate for the core body temperature of the individual.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The measured temperature.
The measurement of the longest distance around the head.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The measurement of the longest distance around the head.
Blood oxygen and related measurements, measured by pulse oximetry or pulse CO-oximetry.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The saturation of oxygen in the peripheral blood, measured via pulse oximetry.

annotations.comment: SpO is defined as the percentage of oxyhaemoglobin (HbO) to the total concentration of haemoglobin (HbO + deoxyhaemoglobin) in peripheral blood.

localizedDescriptions.en: Calculated measurement which compares a person's weight and height.

annotations.comment: Body Mass Index is a calculated ratio describing how an individual's body weight relates to the weight that is regarded as normal, or desirable, for the individual's height.

localizedDescriptions.en: Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Index describing ratio of weight to height.
The local measurement of arterial blood pressure which is a surrogate for arterial pressure in the systemic circulation.

annotations.comment: Most commonly, use of the term 'blood pressure' refers to measurement of brachial artery pressure in the upper arm.

localizedDescriptions.en: Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Peak systemic arterial blood pressure  - measured in systolic or contraction phase of the heart cycle.
Minimum systemic arterial blood pressure - measured in the diastolic or relaxation phase of the heart cycle.
A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
Details about a single identified health condition, injury, disability or any other issue which impacts on the physical, mental and/or social well-being of an individual.

annotations.comment: Clear delineation between the scope of a problem versus a diagnosis is not easy to achieve in practice. For the purposes of clinical documentation with this archetype, problem and diagnosis are regarded as a continuum, with increasing levels of detail and supportive evidence usually providing weight towards the label of 'diagnosis'.

localizedDescriptions.en: Identification of the problem or diagnosis, by name.

annotations.comment: Coding of the name of the problem or diagnosis with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: Specific variant or subtype of the Diagnosis, if relevant.

annotations.comment: For example: 'acute motor axonal neuropathy' as a variant of Guillain-Barre Syndrome. Coding of the name of the variant with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: Identification of a simple body site for the location of the problem or diagnosis.

annotations.comment:
Coding of the name of the anatomical location with a terminology is preferred, where possible.
Use this data element to record precoordinated anatomical locations. If the requirements for recording the anatomical location are determined at run-time by the application or require more complex modelling such as relative locations then use the CLUSTER.anatomical_location or CLUSTER.relative_location within the 'Structured anatomical location' SLOT in this archetype. Occurrences for this data element are unbounded to allow for clinical scenarios such as describing a rash in multiple locations but where all of the other attributes are identical. If the anatomical location is included in the Problem/diagnosis name via precoordinated codes, this data element becomes redundant.

localizedDescriptions.en: A cause, set of causes, or manner of causation of the problem or diagnosis.

annotations.comment: Also known as 'aetiology' or 'etiology'. Coding with an external terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: Estimated or actual date/time that signs or symptoms of the problem/diagnosis were first observed.

annotations.comment: Data captured/imported as "Age at onset" should be converted to a date using the subject's date of birth.

localizedDescriptions.en: An assessment of the overall severity of the problem or diagnosis.

annotations.comment: If severity is included in the Problem/diagnosis name via precoordinated codes, this data element becomes redundant. Note: more specific grading of severity can be recorded using the Specific details SLOT.

localizedDescriptions.en: The problem or diagnosis does not interfere with normal activity or may cause damage to health if left untreated.
The problem or diagnosis causes interference with normal activity or will damage health if left untreated.
The problem or diagnosis prevents normal activity or will seriously damage health if left untreated.
Estimated or actual date/time of resolution or remission for this problem or diagnosis, as determined by a healthcare professional.

annotations.comment: Partial dates are acceptable. If the subject of care is under the age of one year, then the complete date or a minimum of the month and year is necessary to enable accurate age calculations - for example, if used to drive decision support. Data captured/imported as "Age at time of resolution" should be converted to a date using the subject's date of birth.

localizedDescriptions.en: Contextual or temporal qualifier for a specified problem or diagnosis.
Category that supports division of problems and diagnoses into Active or Inactive problem lists.

annotations.comment: The Active/Inactive and Current/Past data elements have similar clinical impact but represent slightly different semantics. Both are actively used in different clinical settings, but usually not together. If a Current/Past qualifier is recorded, then this data element is likely to be redundant. An exception where a condition can be current but inactive is asthma that is not causing acute symptoms.

localizedDescriptions.en: The problem or diagnosis is currently active and clinically relevant.
The problem or diagnosis is not completely resolved but is inactive or felt less relevant to the current clinical context.
Phase of healing for an acute problem or diagnosis.

annotations.comment: For example: tracking the progress of resolution of a middle ear infection.

localizedDescriptions.en: Problem or diagnosis has completed the normal phases of restoration or healing and can be considered resolved.
Problem or diagnosis has deteriorated after a period of temporary improvement.
Status of the remission of an incurable diagnosis.

annotations.comment: For example: the status of a cancer or haematological diagnosis.

localizedDescriptions.en: No ongoing signs or symptoms of the disease have been identified.
Category of the occurrence for this problem or diagnosis.

annotations.comment: This data element can be an additional qualifier to the 'New' value in the 'Episodicity' value set, that is a condition such as asthma can have recurring new episodes that have periods of resolution in between. However it can be important to identify the first ever episode of asthma from all of the other episodes.

localizedDescriptions.en: New occurrence of the same problem or diagnosis after a previous episode was resolved.
The level of confidence in the identification of the diagnosis.

annotations.comment: If an alternative valueset is required, these values can be added to the DV_TEXT data type in a template.

localizedDescriptions.en: The diagnosis has been identified with a low level of certainty.
The diagnosis has been identified with a high level of certainty.
The diagnosis has been confirmed against recognised criteria.
The date this problem or diagnosis was last updated.
A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
Overview or summary record of a pregnancy and outcome, including the antenatal period, labour, birth and the immediate postnatal period.
Statement about the current status of a single pregnancy.

annotations.comment:
For example: pre-pregnant, such as intending to get pregnant, not taking contraception, actively undertaking IVF treatment; pregnant; post-partum.
This status could be designated as 'pre-pregnant' to initiate care pathways for a woman actively attempting to conceive, to ensure that clinical management carefully avoids treatment that could harm a mother or fetus in an unrecognised pregnancy.

localizedDescriptions.en: An informal identifier assigned to the pregnancy, used to distinguish it from other pregnancies.

annotations.comment: For example: '1', 'Triplet', or 'Sam'."

localizedDescriptions.en: An informal identifier assigned to the pregnancy, used to distinguish it from other pregnancies.
An informal identifier assigned to the pregnancy, used to distinguish it from other pregnancies.
Confirmation of the pregnancy.

annotations.comment: Confirmation may be documented either by date, boolean selection or a link to a confirmatory test result within the health record. This data element may be used to trigger a 'Current' 'Pregnancy status' within the EVALUATION.pregnancy_status archetype.

localizedDescriptions.en: Confirmation of the pregnancy.
Confirmation of the pregnancy.
Confirmation of the pregnancy.
Narrative description about the entire pregnancy, labour and delivery, including complications.

annotations.comment: This data element may be used to populate the 'Pregnancy/birth synopsis' data element within the EVALUATION.birth_details archetype in an infant health record.

localizedDescriptions.en: Was the pregnancy a result of assisted reproductive technology?

annotations.comment: True, if assisted reproduction was required to achieve the pregnancy.

localizedDescriptions.en: Type of assisted reproductive technology used to achieve pregnancy.

annotations.comment: Coding with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: Outcome of the pregnancy as a whole.

annotations.comment: This data element is only used to record the outcome of a pregnancy, before it is useful to record an outcome on a per fetus basis. For example: a 'miscarriage' or a 'missed abortion'. Coding of the 'Early pregnancy outcome' with an external terminology is recommended. If it is necessary to record outcome information per infant or fetus use the 'Infant outcome' data element instead.  This data element is redundant if 'Infant outcome' has been recorded.

localizedDescriptions.en: The gestation when the pregnancy has ended.

annotations.comment: Also known as 'Gestation at birth' for pregnancies resulting in viable outcomes.

localizedDescriptions.en: The date and/or time marking the end of the pregnancy.

annotations.comment: This data element may be renamed in a template, depending on the pregnancy outcome. For example: date of delivery for a live birth or stillbirth; date of miscarriage; or date of termination.

localizedDescriptions.en: Assertion about whether the pregnancy is cateogrised as 'multiple pregnancy'.

annotations.comment: This categorial data element is commonly required within registries or used in risk assessment, rather than recording the actual 'Number of fetuses'.

localizedDescriptions.en: Assertion about whether the pregnancy is cateogrised as 'multiple pregnancy'.
The pregnancy has more than one fetus.
The pregnancy has only one fetus.
Assertion about whether the pregnancy is cateogrised as 'multiple pregnancy'.
Assertion about whether the pregnancy is cateogrised as 'multiple pregnancy'.
Number of fetuses identified in utero.
Manner in which labour started.
No onset of labour.
Onset without intervention.
Onset through intervention.
Method of labour induction.

annotations.comment: Coding of the 'Induction Method' with a terminology is desirable, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: Reason for induction of labour.
Method of labour augmentation.

annotations.comment: Coding of the 'Augmentation Method' with a terminology is desirable, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: Total duration of all three stages of labour.
Coded or narrative description about the condition of the perineum after birth, including injuries and repairs.
Involve just the skin of the vaginal opening and perineum.
Involve the skin and muscle of the perineum and might extend deep into the vagina.
Tear in the vaginal tissue, perineal skin, and perineal muscles that extends into the anal sphincter.
Extend through the anal sphincter and into the mucous membrane that lines the rectum.
Was an episiotomy performed?
Estimation of total maternal blood loss during birth and immediately postpartum.
Simple details about the  location where the pregnancy was delivered or an alternative outcome of the pregnancy was treated or managed.

annotations.comment: For example: the name of the hospital or clinic.

localizedDescriptions.en: Category of the place where the pregnancy was delivered or an alternative outcome of the pregnancy was treated or managed.

annotations.comment: It is strongly recommended that 'Place category' be coded with an external terminology. For example: hospital; birthing clinic; or home.

localizedDescriptions.en: Details about pregnancy complications or birth complications affecting the mother.

annotations.comment: Maternal complications recorded within this maternal 'Pregnancy summary' archetype may be used to populate EVALUATION.problem_diagnosis or ACTION.procedure archetypes as part of a maternal Problem list, or similar. Alternatively these complications may be derived from relevant entries previously documented in the maternal health record using EVALUATION.problem_diagnosis or ACTION.procedure archetypes.

localizedDescriptions.en: Identification of the complication.

annotations.comment: Coding of the 'Complication' with a terminology is desirable, where possible. For example, post partum haemorrhage or pre-eclampsia.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description of the maternal complication.
Date of onset of complication, as assessed by a clinician.

annotations.comment: If only a partial date is available, this is acceptable.

localizedDescriptions.en: Information about a single fetus or newborn infant.

annotations.comment: These data elements may be used to record details about live births or stillborn infants.

localizedDescriptions.en: Identification of the infant.

annotations.comment: Identification might be by the name of the neonate or a label given to a non-viable fetus.

localizedDescriptions.en: Outcome of the pregnancy for the identified infant or fetus.

annotations.comment: This data element is only used to record the outcome of a pregnancy for a single infant or fetus. For example: 'Live birth'; or 'Stillbirth'. Coding of the 'Infant outcome' with an external terminology is recommended.  If it is necessary to record outcome information for the pregnancy as a whole use the 'Early pregnancy outcome' data element instead. This data element is redundant if 'Early pregnancy outcome' has been recorded.

localizedDescriptions.en: Date and time of delivery for the infant.

annotations.comment: This data element may be used to populate the newborn's health record using the 'Date of birth' data element within the EVALUATION.birth_details archetype.

localizedDescriptions.en: Sex of the infant  by direct observation of external genitalia.

annotations.comment: Coding with a terminology is preferred, where possible. For example: Male; female; intersex; indeterminate. Indeterminate is to be used in the situation where the infant has ambiguous external genitalia. This data element may be used to populate the newborn health record using the 'Sex assigned at birth' data element within the EVALUATION.gender archetype.

localizedDescriptions.en: Baby appears physically male.
Baby appears physically female.
Sex of the baby has not yet been able to be determined from observation of physical characteristics.
Presenting part of the infant at delivery.

annotations.comment: The clinical context for recording this data element is only presentation at delivery, not at any other phase of labour.

localizedDescriptions.en: The vertex was the presenting part.
The breech was the presenting part.
The face was the presenting part.
The brow was the presenting part.
A foot was the presenting part.
An arm was the presenting part.
A shoulder was the presenting part.
Position of the infant at delivery.
The baby's back was toward the left side of the uterus at onset of labour.
The baby's back was toward the right side of the uterus at onset of labour.
It is not known which side the baby's back was positioned by onset of labour.
Weight of the infant at delivery.

annotations.comment: This data element may be used to populate the newborn health record using both the 'Weight' data element and 'Birth' EVENT within the OBSERVATION.body_weight archetype.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description about feeding of the infant.
Description of the outcome at the end of the neonatal period per newborn infant.
The infant survived the neonatal period.
The infant did not survive the neonatal period.
Narrative description about issues, concerns about the infant or events occurring during the neonatal period.
The age of the infant if they died during the neonatal  period.
Details about any complications affecting the newborn.

annotations.comment: Newborn complications recorded within this maternal 'Pregnancy summary' archetype may be used to populate EVALUATION.problem_diagnosis or ACTION.procedure archetypes to initiate a Problem list, or similar, within a newborn health record.

localizedDescriptions.en: Identification of the complication after birth.

annotations.comment: Coding of the 'Complication' with a terminology is desirable, where possible. For example, neonatal hypoglycaemia or hypothermia.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description of complication.
Date and/or time of onset of the complication.
Additional narrative about the infant, not captured in other fields.
Additional narrative about the pregnancy, not captured in other fields.
Estimated date of delivery for a pregnancy.
The EDD calculated from a known date of conception.

annotations.comment: The date of conception will usually be recorded elsewhere in the health record, for example as part of the record for an IVF procedure.

localizedDescriptions.en: The EDD estimated from the onset of the last normal menstrual period by Naegle's method.

annotations.comment: The date of the 'Last menstrual period' will be captured elsewhere using the EVALUATION.last_menstrual_period archetype. In addition, further details about typical cycles will be recorded using the EVALUATION.menstruation_summary and details about a specific menstrual cycle will be recorded using the OBSERVATION.menstruation archetype.

localizedDescriptions.en: Details about an EDD estimated from the findings on a pregnancy ultrasound.

annotations.comment: The findings from each ultrasound will be captured as a separate instance within this CLUSTER.

localizedDescriptions.en: Details about an EDD estimated from the findings on a pregnancy ultrasound.

annotations.comment: Only one 'Agreed EDD' is appropriate at any one time. If the agreed EDD needs to be revised then this should be captured in a new revision of this archetype within a health record.

localizedDescriptions.en: Details about the EDD which is used as the basis for clinical decision-making during the pregnancy.

annotations.comment: This CLUSTER has intentionally been constrained to a single occurrence representing the current agreed date. Amended EDDs should be stored in the health record as previous versions of this archetype.

localizedDescriptions.en: The EDD which is to be used as the basis for clinical decision-making.

annotations.comment: This EDD may be amended during the pregnancy by the healthcare providers to reflect available evidence and the specific circumstances of the pregnancy. For example, an EDD based on an uncertain cycle information may be updated once early ultrasound details become available.

localizedDescriptions.en: The date any EDD was last updated.
Statement to explicitly record that a pregnancy was not present.
An overall statement of exclusion about the state of pregnancy.
A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
Summary or persistent information about the tobacco smoking habits of an individual.
Statement about current smoking behaviour for all types of tobacco.
Individual has never smoked any type of tobacco.
Individual is a current smoker of tobacco.
Individual has previously smoked tobacco but is not a current smoker.
Summary or persistent information about the typical alcohol consumption of an individual.
Statement about current consumption for all types of alcohol.
Individual is a current consumer of alcohol.
Individual has previously consumed alcohol but is not a current drinker.
Individual has never consumed alcohol.
Details about a discrete period of time with a consistent pattern of typical consumption.
Estimate of number of alcohol units consumed.
A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
Plan or sequence of discrete activities developed to achieve a specified management goal or treatment outcome, carried out by health professionals and/or the patient.
Name of care plan.
Description of activity performed/enacted against the plan.
Reason for activity  being performed /enacted against the plan.
Identification of care plan.
Anticipated date beyond which the care plan can be deemed 'expired'.
Request for a health-related service or activity to be delivered by a clinician, organisation or agency.
Current Activity.
The name of the service/s requested.

annotations.comment: Coding of the 'Service name' with an external terminology is strongly recommended, if available. This data element allows multiple occurrences to enable the user to record a multiple services as part of a single request, if required.

localizedDescriptions.en: Category of service requested.

annotations.comment: Coding of the 'Service type' with an external terminology is desirable, if available. If the 'Service name' was coded, it is possible for this data point to be derived from the code.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description about the service requested.

annotations.comment: This data point should be used to describe the named service in more detail, including how it should be delivered, patient concerns and issues that might be encountered in delivering the service.

localizedDescriptions.en: The symptom, sign or diagnosis that necessitates the requested service.

annotations.comment: Coding of the 'Clinical indication' with an external terminology is recommended, if available.  This data element allows multiple occurrences to enable the user to record a multiple responses, if required.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative information about the individual and their situation, providing relevant context for the request.
The specific problem needing attention or the clinical question that requires investigation.

annotations.comment: Coding of the 'Reason for request' with an external terminology is desirable, if available. This data element allows multiple occurrences to enable the user to record a multiple responses, if required.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description about the issue or clinical query that needs resolution.
Description of the intended outcome of the request.

annotations.comment: Coding of the 'Intent' with an external terminology is recommended, if available. This data element allows multiple occurrences to enable the user to record a multiple responses, if required.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional details and instructions about how the services are to be delivered.

annotations.comment: Coding of the 'Order detail' with an external terminology is desirable, if available. This data element allows multiple occurrences to enable the user to record a multiple responses, if required.

localizedDescriptions.en: Urgency of the request for service.

annotations.comment: Specific definitions of emergency and urgent will vary between clinical contexts, clinical systems and the nature of the request itself, so have not been defined in this archetype. More precise timing requirements should be specified using the 'Service due' data element or the CLUSTER.service_direction archetype within the 'Complex timing' SLOT.

localizedDescriptions.en: The request requires immediate attention.
The request requires prioritised attention.
The request does not require prioritised scheduling.
The date/time or description about timing for provision of the requested service/s.

annotations.comment: This data element allows for recording of the timing for the service/s, either as a date and time, an interval of date and time, or a text descriptor. In practice, clinicians will often think in terms of ordering services as relative or approximate timing, for example: 'next available', or  in '3 months'. As clinical systems need more exact parameters to operate on, this '3 months' will usually be converted to an exact date 3 months from the date of recording and stored using this data element. If complex timing or sequences of timings are required, use the CLUSTER.service_direction archetype within the 'Complex timing' SLOT and this data element becomes redundant.

localizedDescriptions.en: The date/time or description about timing for provision of the requested service/s.
The date/time or description about timing for provision of the requested service/s.
The date/time or description about timing for provision of the requested service/s.
Supplementary information will be following request.

annotations.comment: Record as TRUE if additional information has been identified and will be forwarded when available. For example: pending test results.

localizedDescriptions.en: Description of the supplementary information.
Additional narrative about the service request not captured in other fields.
The local identifier assigned by the requesting clinical system.

annotations.comment: Usually equivalent to the HL7 Placer Order Identifier.

localizedDescriptions.en: The local identifier assigned by the requesting clinical system.
The local identifier assigned by the requesting clinical system.
The local identifier assigned to the request by the clinician or organisation receiving the request for service.

annotations.comment: Usually equivalent to the HL7 Filler Order Identifier.

localizedDescriptions.en: The local identifier assigned to the request by the clinician or organisation receiving the request for service.
The local identifier assigned to the request by the clinician or organisation receiving the request for service.
The status of the request for service as indicated by the requester.

annotations.comment: Status is used to denote whether this is the initial request, or a follow-up request to change or provide supplementary information. Coding with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: Advice from the requester to the receiver about the individual's eligibility for the requested service.
A recommendation from the requester to the receiver about the method of payment for the service.

annotations.comment: For example: 'Private'; 'Government insurance scheme'; or 'Private insurance'.

localizedDescriptions.en: A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
Details about a single identified health condition, injury, disability or any other issue which impacts on the physical, mental and/or social well-being of an individual.

annotations.comment: Clear delineation between the scope of a problem versus a diagnosis is not easy to achieve in practice. For the purposes of clinical documentation with this archetype, problem and diagnosis are regarded as a continuum, with increasing levels of detail and supportive evidence usually providing weight towards the label of 'diagnosis'.

localizedDescriptions.en: Identification of the problem or diagnosis, by name.

annotations.comment: Coding of the name of the problem or diagnosis with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: Specific variant or subtype of the Diagnosis, if relevant.

annotations.comment: For example: 'acute motor axonal neuropathy' as a variant of Guillain-Barre Syndrome. Coding of the name of the variant with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: Identification of a simple body site for the location of the problem or diagnosis.

annotations.comment:
Coding of the name of the anatomical location with a terminology is preferred, where possible.
Use this data element to record precoordinated anatomical locations. If the requirements for recording the anatomical location are determined at run-time by the application or require more complex modelling such as relative locations then use the CLUSTER.anatomical_location or CLUSTER.relative_location within the 'Structured anatomical location' SLOT in this archetype. Occurrences for this data element are unbounded to allow for clinical scenarios such as describing a rash in multiple locations but where all of the other attributes are identical. If the anatomical location is included in the Problem/diagnosis name via precoordinated codes, this data element becomes redundant.

annotations.comment: Also known as 'aetiology' or 'etiology'. Coding with an external terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: Estimated or actual date/time that signs or symptoms of the problem/diagnosis were first observed.

annotations.comment: Data captured/imported as "Age at onset" should be converted to a date using the subject's date of birth.

localizedDescriptions.en: An assessment of the overall severity of the problem or diagnosis.

annotations.comment: If severity is included in the Problem/diagnosis name via precoordinated codes, this data element becomes redundant. Note: more specific grading of severity can be recorded using the Specific details SLOT.

localizedDescriptions.en: The problem or diagnosis does not interfere with normal activity or may cause damage to health if left untreated.
The problem or diagnosis causes interference with normal activity or will damage health if left untreated.
The problem or diagnosis prevents normal activity or will seriously damage health if left untreated.
Estimated or actual date/time of resolution or remission for this problem or diagnosis, as determined by a healthcare professional.

annotations.comment: Partial dates are acceptable. If the subject of care is under the age of one year, then the complete date or a minimum of the month and year is necessary to enable accurate age calculations - for example, if used to drive decision support. Data captured/imported as "Age at time of resolution" should be converted to a date using the subject's date of birth.

localizedDescriptions.en: Contextual or temporal qualifier for a specified problem or diagnosis.
Category that supports division of problems and diagnoses into Active or Inactive problem lists.

annotations.comment: The Active/Inactive and Current/Past data elements have similar clinical impact but represent slightly different semantics. Both are actively used in different clinical settings, but usually not together. If a Current/Past qualifier is recorded, then this data element is likely to be redundant. An exception where a condition can be current but inactive is asthma that is not causing acute symptoms.

localizedDescriptions.en: The problem or diagnosis is currently active and clinically relevant.
The problem or diagnosis is not completely resolved but is inactive or felt less relevant to the current clinical context.
Phase of healing for an acute problem or diagnosis.

annotations.comment: For example: tracking the progress of resolution of a middle ear infection.

localizedDescriptions.en: Problem or diagnosis has completed the normal phases of restoration or healing and can be considered resolved.
Problem or diagnosis has deteriorated after a period of temporary improvement.
Status of the remission of an incurable diagnosis.

annotations.comment: For example: the status of a cancer or haematological diagnosis.

localizedDescriptions.en: No ongoing signs or symptoms of the disease have been identified.
Category of the occurrence for this problem or diagnosis.

annotations.comment: This data element can be an additional qualifier to the 'New' value in the 'Episodicity' value set, that is a condition such as asthma can have recurring new episodes that have periods of resolution in between. However it can be important to identify the first ever episode of asthma from all of the other episodes.

localizedDescriptions.en: New occurrence of the same problem or diagnosis after a previous episode was resolved.
The level of confidence in the identification of the diagnosis.

annotations.comment: If an alternative valueset is required, these values can be added to the DV_TEXT data type in a template.

localizedDescriptions.en: The diagnosis has been identified with a low level of certainty.
The diagnosis has been identified with a high level of certainty.
The diagnosis has been confirmed against recognised criteria.
The date this problem or diagnosis was last updated.
Narrative summary or overview about a patient, specifically from the perspective of a healthcare provider, and with or without associated interpretations.
The summary, assessment, conclusions or evaluation of the clinical findings.
